bibl.note: This is a letter dated February 15, 1818 from William Martin in Dixon Springs, Tennessee to Winchester & Cage in Cairo, Tennessee. The letter covers several subjects including, importantly, remarks concerning a decision to send a branch of the United States bank to Nashville.

div1.p: Your favor of the 6th Inst by my son Brian, was recd in due time, but was not answered by his return to Cairo, quiry to other & prossiry engagements. I now avail myself of the oppty to inform you, that the explanations given in that letter, respecting my son__ is satisfactory. and I repeat my wish for him to continue in your service. We hear that about 1200 Volunters appeared at Fayettville, for the purpose of proceeding to the south. Their commander (Col Hayns) declared, he knew not their destination. we also hear, that a large force go from the cherokees__ on the same expedition. That this force is intended to act agst Florida, is inforced on the mind by a combination of circumstances, which with me leaves no doubt on the subject.

Our court of pleas & quarter sessions is organized under the late act of assembly (members) Wilson Cage__ Richd Alexander__ Patrick M Erhern__ William Haney, & Branch Nunly. The three first named are good assts__ the others might have been lecttured However upon the whole, we have done pretty well, and I anticipate much good to result from it. Hoping that any defeats which experience may discover in the system, will be provided for by the next genl assembly. I am glad
that the directors of the U States bank have determined to send a branch to Nashville The resolution of Our legislature to the contrary not withstanding. I am also glad that that the people are well disposed to recieve it. Should this inquir the profits of the state banks. What is that to you, or me, or the people gennerally I say nothing provided a better is substituted__ and that it will be better, I believe now am prepared to deny.
a gentleman late from Huntsville say that, at the late sales of public land there, it averaged $48 per acre and the best not yet sold. If this be true, it baffles a conjecture.

Congress has at last discharged Col John Anderson from confinment, with a repremand. This mans tenacity opened a new and wide field for the display of congressional eloquence, & learning__ and which has been well improved. altho much time has on this subject been occupied, which might have been usefully employed in attending to the great concens of the nation, It may nevertheless be considered well spent, as it has probably settled that principle forever.

Our family are in health, hoping you & yours are enjoying the like blessing. I say blessings, because it may justly be ranked among the greatest which this state of existance affords, and is necessary to sustain all the risk. without it, life is an unplea
sent & undesireable thing.
div1.closer:
With due respect & high consideration I am gentlemen your most obd Hol Sevt Wm MartinMajor Winchester & Cage
Col. William Martin 15th Fey 1818 Dixon Spring Tn16th Feby 1818 Major Winchester & Cage Cairo Tennessee mail
